claim.text: below 19°C, occupants report cold feet regardless of air temperature
claim.claim: ASHRAE Standard 55 indicates occupants report cold feet below 19°C floor temperature regardless of air temperature

results.summary: ASHRAE Standard 55 does specify 19°C as the lower floor surface temperature limit for thermal comfort, below which cold feet discomfort occurs.
results.detail: ASHRAE Standard 55 specifies floor surface temperatures should be between 19°C and 29°C (66°F to 84°F) for sedentary occupants with typical footwear. The 19°C lower limit is established based on research by Ole Fanger and others demonstrating that floor contact temperature significantly affects thermal sensation at the feet, with discomfort occurring below this threshold regardless of air temperature. The claim accurately represents the standard's guidance on local thermal discomfort from floor surfaces.
sources: ASHRAE Standard 55: Thermal Environmental Conditions for Human Occupancy
Fanger, P.O. thermal comfort research (foundational research for ASHRAE 55)
